tip.text:
Encourage your child’s explorations
with related science books.
Visit the Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf

Get your kids engaged in science everyday
with help from our Explorer’s Guide.
Learn more

Find related science activities that
you can share with your kids.
Go!

Learn more about the educational
approach behind the show.
Visit PBS Parents

Use the mapping tool to create a drawing
of where your child lives.
Ask him/her to find some hidden objects. Learn More.

Want to find more Cat in the Hat science
activities to share with your kids?
Visit PBS Parents.

Find more ways to encourage your
child’s natural curiosity in
The Cat in the Hat’s Explorer’s Guide.

Extend the fun with more activities
made especially for parents.
Learn More!

Your child can observe birds by
building their own birdfeeder.
Find out how!

Try visiting a zoo or bird sanctuary to
observe many different types of birds.
More bird activities.

Help your child hone their observation skills by
drawing pictures of birds they see near home.
Learn more.

Try playing your own game of hide-and-seek at home. Then
talk about what made it easy or hard to find someone.
Get more ideas!

Try looking for animals that are
hiding in your own backyard.
Learn more.

Take a trip to the zoo and let your kids
draw their animal observations.
Get the activity!

Your child can record their weather observations
with their own weather chart.
Get the activity!

Grab an ice cube from the freezer and extend
your child’s weather exploration.
Find out how!

Something as simple as splashing in rain puddles
can spark your child’s curiosity about weather.
Find more ideas!

What does nighttime smell like? Take a nighttime walk with
your child and discuss how things smell different at night.
Find more ideas!

Make a sensory salad! Then ask your child to
identify the ingredients by touch, smell, and taste.
Find more ideas!

Visit a nocturnal animals exhibit at your zoo, then ask your
child to make a list of the nocturnal animals that live near you.
Find more ideas!

Invite your child to be a flower detective! Visit a plant nursery
or wildflower farm and look at and smell interesting flowers.
Find more ideas!

Encourage your child to watch a bee, butterfly, or other
insect browsing a flower. Discuss your child's observations.
Find more ideas!

Together with your child, pick or purchase some
interesting flowers to take home for pressing.
Find more ideas!

Invite your child to be an animal detective by looking at
and listening for animals that live in trees.
Find more ideas!

Make a book of your child's leaf
and bark rubbings.
Find more ideas!

Go to a local zoo or animal habitat and spend time
with your child observing animals that live in trees.
Find more ideas!

Find out the science approach behind
the program at PBS Parents.
Learn More!

Want to help your child understand the big
science ideas in each episode?
Get the episode descriptions.

Did you know the show is based on the
Dr. Seuss Learning Library books?
Visit the Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf.

Help your child get the most
out of every episode.
Read our viewing tips!

Comparing and contrasting is just one of the
ways your child can think like a scientist.
Find more ways.

Taking pictures with your child is a great way to get
your child engaged in observation and exploration.
Get more ideas.

You can always find more photos of
nature by looking in a book.
Check out The Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf.

Comparing and contrasting is just one of the
ways your child can think like a scientist.
Find more ways.

Taking pictures with your child is a great way to get
your child engaged in observation and exploration.
Get more ideas.

You can always find more photos of
nature by looking in a book.
Check out The Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf.

Comparing and contrasting is just one of the
ways your child can think like a scientist.
Find more ways.

Taking pictures with your child is a great way to get
your child engaged in observation and exploration.
Get more ideas.

You can always find more photos of
nature by looking in a book.
Check out The Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf.

Comparing and contrasting is just one of the
ways your child can think like a scientist.
Find more ways.

Taking pictures with your child is a great way to get
your child engaged in observation and exploration.
Get more ideas.

You can always find more photos of
nature by looking in a book.
Check out The Cat in the Hat’s Science Bookshelf.

Invite your child to draw twohouses, one that is
just the right size for the Cat and another
that is just the right size for Sally and Nick.

Hone your child’s sorting and measurement skills
by making and playing the Hermit Shell Game

Invite your child to draw pictures of kites
and discuss which shapes might float the best.

Lie on your backs on a cloudy day and watch
the wind blow the clouds. Point out and discuss
the different shapes you can see in the sky.

Match the pasta! Get a bunch of differently
shaped pasta and mix them up in a bowl. Then ask
your child to sort the pasta into like piles.

Tasty shapes! Together with your child, make
edible shapes out of sandwich bread or cookie dough.

Get in shape! Take a walk with your child
and search for shapes. Bring a camera and
snap pictures of the shapes.

Help familiarize your child with shapes by
reading Shapes, Shapes, Shapes, by Tana Hoban.

Have your child cut out shapes from
construction paper. Then see what pictures your child
can make by putting the shaped pieces together.

Make a shape sorter by helping your child
cut shapes into the lid of a shoebox.

Clean shapes! Cut shapes out of clean,
colorful sponges and invite your child to
wash-and-learn.

Invite your child to draw pictures of kites
and discuss which shapes might float the best.

Lie on your backs on a cloudy day and watch
the wind blow the clouds. Point out and discuss
the different shapes you can see in the sky.

Match the pasta! Get a bunch of differently
shaped pasta and mix them up in a bowl. Then ask
your child to sort the pasta into like piles.

Tasty shapes! Together with your child, make
edible shapes out of sandwich bread or cookie dough.

Get in shape! Take a walk with your child
and search for shapes. Bring a camera and
snap pictures of the shapes.

Help familiarize your child with shapes by
reading Shapes, Shapes, Shapes, by Tana Hoban.

Have your child cut out shapes from
construction paper. Then see what pictures your child
can make by putting the shaped pieces together.

Make a shape sorter by helping your child
cut shapes into the lid of a shoebox.

Clean shapes! Cut shapes out of clean,
colorful sponges and invite your child to
wash-and-learn.

Invite your child to draw twohouses, one that is
just the right size for the Cat and another
that is just the right size for Sally and Nick.

Hone your child’s sorting and measurement skills
by making and playing the Hermit Shell Game

Choose three objects of varying heights,
and challenge your child to put them in order
from shortest to tallest.

Use a pencil to measure different things
around the house,even your child!
How many pencils long is the sofa?

Match ’em up! Get three jars or food storage containers
with different sized lids. Ask your child
to match the lids to the jars.

Use position clues to direct your child
where to place a small stuffed animal on her body
(e.g., on top of your head; under your arm).

Create an indoor obstacle course, and ask your child
to describe his position as he goes through it using words
such asover, under, and between.

Make a simple map of a room.Hide something,
and put an X on the map to show its location.
Ask your child to use the map to find the object.

Use position clues to direct your child
where to place a small stuffed animal on her body
(e.g., on top of your head; under your arm).

Create an indoor obstacle course, and ask your child
to describe his position as he goes through it using words
such asover, under, and between.

Make a simple map of a room.Hide something,
and put an X on the map to show its location.
Ask your child to use the map to find the object.

Create a personal puzzle. Print out a family photo,
paste it onto heavy paper, and cut it into
five or six puzzle pieces. Print an extra to use as a guide.

Challenge your child to set a table so that one side
looks exactly the same as the side across from it.
That’s symmetry!

Ask your child to draw the path of his ideal roller-coaster
and then describe the path using position words
such as up, down, under, and over.

For the same “sort” of fun at home,
help your child sort everyday objects
(like coins, blocks, or candy) by color, shape, and size.

Leaves moving too fast?
Click the apple at the top of the screen
to change the speed.

Your child can make real-life leaf art too!
Gather a bunch of leaves with different shapes,
and glue them to a sheet of paper to make a picture.

Make a guessing game about your family! Give one clue at a time
about a mystery family member, until your child guesses who
it is: A grown-up or kid? Boy or girl? Blue eyes or brown?

Make sure to look carefully for all the fish that fit!
There might be more than one fish with glasses,
or a few fish with pig noses.

With a crayon and paper, your child can make pretend birds
and land animals too. What weird and wacky bodies could they
have? What would a bird do with wheels instead of wings?

Go on a smell hunt of your own!
What smells can you identify with your eyes closed?
Soap? Chocolate? A flower?

Do you eat sardines? Real-life dolphins do!
Help your dolphin grab the sardines
for a burst of energy.

For more wintry fun, compare real animal tracks
– or your own family’s footprints -- in the mud or snow.
Whose footprints are biggest or smallest?

Put ten small objects on a table. Cover up some
of them with a napkin. Ask your child
how many are hiding under the napkin.

Give your child seven pennies
and ask him how many ways he can make seven.
For example, three pennies and four pennies;
or five pennies and two pennies.

Play a number guessing game with your child:
"I am thinking of a number.
When you add "one" to it you get "six." What’s my number?"

Talk with your child about who lives next door,
across the street (or corridor in an apartment building),
and what two neighbors you live between.

Play location I Spy— a twist on the classic
I Spy game with directional clues
(e.g., “I spy something red under the table”).

Ask your child to describe how she would walk
from the front door to the kitchen, using position words
such as around, through, up, and down.
